channel.title: Audit on The Sovereign Library
channel.description: Recent content in Audit on The Sovereign Library

item.title: Substance Audit: Neurochemical Tool Deployment
item.description:
Summary: Frame substance history as functional tool deployment. Audit function/ROI, adopt or decommission. History becomes a log of tool iteration.

Source: Raw Transcripts TXT: Batches 2–5

Core Principle

These are tools, not moral failures. The question is function and ROI, not shame.

Audit Questions

  1. What function does this tool serve?
  2. What is the current ROI?
  3. Is it building sovereignty or compensating for a deficit?
  4. Should it be adopted, modified, or decommissioned?

RCP Integration

All neurochemical tools are subject to RCP filter: “Which unmet need is this currently compensating for?”

item.title: Substance Progression Timeline (Tool History)
item.description:
Summary: Mapped progression: tobacco early teens; alcohol social; herbál betrayal/medical escape; weed modulation/ROI decline; mushrooms in stasis; Xanax rejected.

Source: Raw Transcripts: Batch 4

Framing

Not “use” — tool deployment history. Each substance had a function, an ROI, and eventually a decommission decision.

Key Insight

The operational style is telling: while most teens hid their stash, you scheduled a meeting with your parents.

Status

Historical log. Current deployment governed by RCP.
